keyTakeAways: Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestinian solidarity activist, was detained by U.S. immigration authorities in March 2025 over his activism at Columbia University.
The U.S. government attempted to deport Khalil, alleging that his presence had 'adverse foreign policy consequences' under an immigration law provision invoked by the Trump administration.
Khalil’s case is significant because he was the first prominent Palestinian rights advocate to face deportation over campus activism, setting a precedent for similar cases.
A federal district court in New Jersey granted Khalil’s habeas corpus petition in June 2025, ordering his release from detention, which is not a final resolution of his immigration case.
The government claims Khalil concealed his work with UNRWA on visa and Green Card applications, which the ACLU and Khalil’s lawyers dispute as a basis for deportation.
An immigration judge in 2025 sided with the government and ordered Khalil’s removal, but this decision is currently being appealed to the Board of Immigration Appeals.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) argues that the administration’s use of foreign policy grounds to justify deportations is unconstitutional and amounts to government censorship of free speech.
A separate U.S. judge ruled in 2025 that the Trump administration’s broader crackdown on Palestine solidarity activists violated constitutional free speech protections.
The ongoing legal battle reflects a larger national debate over the balance between immigration enforcement and free expression of political views.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian solidarity activist and legal permanent resident, was detained in March 2025 by U.S. immigration authorities following his activism at Columbia University. He was released in June 2025 by a federal district court in New Jersey on a habeas corpus petition, which challenged the legality of his detention. The government argues that Khalil’s presence poses adverse foreign policy consequences and that he concealed his work with UNRWA on immigration forms, justifying deportation. However, the ACLU and Khalil’s legal team assert that using foreign policy grounds to deport individuals for expressing political opinions violates constitutional free speech protections. While the habeas petition is under appeal, the government’s immigration judge previously ordered Khalil’s removal, which is now being reviewed by the Board of Immigration Appeals. A separate judicial ruling found that the Trump administration’s broader crackdown on Palestine solidarity activists is unlawful, violating free speech rights. The case is central to a larger national debate over whether immigration enforcement can be used as a tool to silence political dissent.
